name: Accountant
description: AI can automate bookkeeping and tax preparation, but complex financial planning and regulatory interpretation still require human expertise.

name: Customer Service Representative
description: AI chatbots and voice assistants are increasingly capable of handling customer queries, especially for standardized issues. Human reps are still needed for complex or emotionally sensitive interactions.

name: Construction Worker
description: Physical labor, adaptability to changing environments, and safety considerations make this role difficult to automate with current AI and robotics.

name: Data Entry Clerk
description: AI and automation tools can process, extract, and input data far faster and more accurately than humans, making this role highly susceptible to replacement.

name: Graphic Designer
description: AI tools can generate images, logos, and layouts quickly, but lack the nuanced creativity and brand understanding that human designers bring. AI may replace basic design tasks but not high-level creative direction.

name: Software Engineer
description: Currently AI can write code, however it is not always the best code or even correct code, usually a programmer paired with AI can be a more efficient programmer, however at least for now, AI is not a solve of the problem, merely a tool to aid the engineers.

name: Teacher
description: While AI can assist with personalized learning and grading, the human connection, mentorship, and classroom management provided by teachers are difficult to replicate.

name: Truck Driver
description: Autonomous vehicle technology is advancing, but widespread adoption faces regulatory, safety, and infrastructure hurdles. Human drivers remain essential for now, especially in complex or rural environments.

name: Lawyer
description: AI can assist with legal research and document review, but legal strategy, courtroom advocacy, and client counseling require human judgment and ethical reasoning.

name: Journalist
description: AI can generate basic news reports and summaries, but investigative journalism, interviews, and nuanced storytelling still rely heavily on human insight.
